0.user_question:
The data in the table below shows the percent of bus riders in a survey of Central H.S. students; 300 males and 300 females in each grade were surveyed. For which grade is the number of its male bus riders closest to $135\%$ of the number of its female bus riders? \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|}\hline
Grade & Males & Females \\ \hline
$9^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $41.1\%$ & $39.4\%$ \\ \hline
$10^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $34.4\%$ & $33.1\%$ \\ \hline
$11^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $20.6\%$ & $13.8\%$ \\ \hline
$12^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $11.6\%$ & $8.6\%$ \\ \hline
\end{tabular}

direct_answer.text:
We need to calculate $135\%$ times the percentage of female bus riders for each grade and compare it to the corresponding value listed under 'Males'. Let's do this calculation:
For 9th graders - $135\% * 39.4\% = 52.79\%$, which differs most closely compared to actual figures ($41.1\%$) among other grades because $|52.79-41.1|$= $11.69$ vs absolute differences like |52.79-39.4|=$13.39$, |52.79-34.4|=$18.39$, etc.. Thus Grade 9 has Male Bus Riders Closest To $135\%$ Of FEMALE BUS RIDERS OF THIS GRADUATION. Answer: Nineth Gradiate .

The data in the table below shows the percent of bus riders in a survey of Central H.S. students; 300 males and 300 females in each grade were surveyed. For which grade is the number of its male bus riders closest to $135\%$ of the number of its female bus riders? \begin{tabular}{|l|c|c|}\hline
Grade & Males & Females \\ \hline
$9^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $41.1\%$ & $39.4\%$ \\ \hline
$10^{\mathrm{th}}$ grade & $34.4\%$ & $33.1\%$ \\ \hline

direct_answer.text:
We need to calculate $135\%$ times the percentage of female bus riders for each grade and compare it to the corresponding value listed under 'Males'. Let's do this calculation:
For 9th graders - $135\% * 39.4\% = 52.79\%$, which differs most closely compared to actual figures ($41.1\%$) among other grades because $|52.79-41.1|$= $11.69$ vs absolute differences like |52.79-39.4|=$13.39$, |52.79-34.4|=$18.39$, etc.. Thus Grade 9 has Male Bus Riders Closest To $135\%$ Of FEMALE BUS RIDERS OF THIS GRADUATION. Answer: Nineth Gradiate .

direct_answer.text:
To solve this problem, let us analyze the provided data row by row. Remember, our goal here involves finding out when the percentage count of male passengers exceeds that of females by approximately `135%`. Let’s calculate how much larger the percentage of male passengers needs to be compared to the percentage of female passengers based on this criterion - i.e., `(PercentageMale / PercentageFemale)` equals about `2.35` (`135%`, expressed mathematically would equate to roughly twice plus thirty five hundredths times higher). Now, using those calculated criteria mentioned above lets compare them sequentially against respective grades starting with `$9^{th}$, up until `$12^{th}$`:

For `$9^{th}$`: Calculated ratio comes out `-0.016`; meaning girls had slightly better rider participation.
For `$10^{th}$`: Ratios come out closer but still lesser likewise. Hence, doesn’t meet required condition yet.
For `$11^{th}$$: Here the value leaps beyond expectation since now boys clearly take lead over girl participants albeit not reaching desired threshold completely though very close.
